title: Twitter Sentiment in Financial Domain

author: Miha Grčar, Department of Knowledge Technologies, Jožef Stefan Institute

segmentation: I will give a short demo a short presentation about extracting sentiment sentiment on financial objects such as stocks from Twitter posts.
So most of you, I guess, know what Twitter is.
It's a web platform for sending short messages, kind of like SMS, but the difference is that SMS is 1 to one more like a channel, and then Twitter is into the air kind of channel.
This is a typical Twitter page.
It's actually our project page where we were.
We would advertise the events.
We would point out some interesting stuff that we find on the web and we would talk about our research progress.
And.
A lot of people are tweeting, so it's estimated that there is 200.
How many 220 million users, and in 2010 they have added 100 million accounts, right?
So these are big numbers.
And all these people produce roughly 65 million tweets every day.
So Twitter is accessible from practically anywhere, obviously from your computer right from your smartphone from your stupid phone from your space station, and so on, right?
So to give you an idea how much traffic is generated on Twitter.
When Michael Jackson died right 450 roughly 450 tweets per second were generated about this event.
When Steve Jobs died, 10,000 tweets were generated about this event and there's this record 25,000 tweets per second.
When in Japan they were screening a cartoon called Castle in the Sky, right?
So these are some to give you an idea of how much traffic is there.
Of course, in all this traffic there's also a lot of people talking talking about finance about stock trading about companies, and about four X and so on.
So they would use something called$$ Convention and I will just give here some examples so.
So there's this one user here saying that Apple is making an announcement at 9:00 AM on what what it plans to do with it.
Scale with its cash, right?
So when the user says Apple, he doesn't say Apple, but it puts a dollar sign and puts the stock ticker symbol right?
So this is very good because we can from all these masses of tweets we can extract tweets, talking about stock trading and companies by searching.
Sorry by searching for these kind of dollar signs.
So what we do is we acquire roughly 13,000 tweets every week day and this is on roughly 100 one 1800 stocks like Google, eBay, Yahoo and so on.
And we analyze the vocabulary in these tweets to determine the sentiment, whether it's positive or negative.
Um?
So.
I would like to now show you.
2 demos and the first one.
I have it in a video.
The video has called out, you know, these bubbles with text, but I will basically read them to you so you don't have to read them.
So the user comes to this system that we have developed and the user expresses his interest.
In this case, it's about Euro again.
You can see this.
He uses the Dollar sign convention here.
So the tweets about era are returned so that Twitter is queried for tweets about era and the results and then the vocabulary is analyzed and the results are presented to the user.
So here you see that we have collected 100 tweets in total and we have.
Thrown out, roughly half of them.
They were near duplicates.
An non English to it, so we remove those and we are left with roughly 55% of negative tweets and 45% of positive tweets, right?
So, um.
If we look at some concrete examples, so there is one saying that euro versus dollar closed below a weekly pivot.
I guess this is some Forex stock and this tweet was recognized as negative of course and there is another one that you markets.
There's a distrust in EU markets, despite some rumors involving ECB, which is supposed to be uplifting.
And this tweet of course was also recognized as negative.
Get some more.
This this tweet is referring to a post which talks about Spain contributing to over the top you depth.
Of course, this is also a negative news, so this tweet was also recognized as negative.
So for some positive tweets so that Italy got a new Prime Minister.
So this was recognized as a positive thing.
Apparently the old one wasn't that good.
And another one where where William Dudley said that he absolutely thinks that your will survive, right?
So these tweets of course were categorized as positive and can you pause it now?
So and I like this one when one of the user says this.
This sounds to me like a pump and dump scenario, right?
So get rid of Eurobic 'cause currently it's it's pumped by this dude ugly guy.
OK, so this is first part of the video of the demo and the rest I will show you on the slides.
Great thanks.
So what you have seen in this video is that we can kind of categorize tweets into positive and negative, right?
What we did here in this graph we collected tweets about Netflix, which is a US company.
Maybe some of you already heard about it.
It's a company that streams TV programs and shows over the Internet.
Right and we collected tweets from.
From March till December.
About net.
And we categorize them as positive and negative sentiment, and we display the results like this along the timeline.
Right and and this blue, this blue line shows you the number of positive tweets, the number of tweets that were detected as positive these.
Line shows you the number of tweets that were detected is negative, right?
And the yellow one will tell you the difference between the positive and the negative tweets.
So if the yellow line is above the zero line, which this means that there were more positive tweets, the negative, and if it's below, it's the other way around.
OK, so green dots are some events concerning Netflix that we entered into the system manually.
And the Gray one is the closing daily closing price for the Netflix stock, right?
OK, So what does this graph tell us?
First of all, this kind of peaks.
These are the volume peaks.
Will tell us.
Did something important happen at this time so people were?
More than usual talking about some event concerning Netflix.
So something happened which is actually true, so we can check out some events.
So this peak here that we're looking at right now.
Is the first quarter earnings release.
Right, so this one here.
It's a smaller one, but still Netflix was planning to launch its service service in in Latin America and the Caribbean, so this was a big news.
This one here, for example, is when Netflix launched a couple of deals for TV shows and movies, and also something called status deal.
I think if I if I remember correctly stars is also one of the networks which they tried to make deals so that the Netflix would stream their programs over the Internet.
So you see, this is already something useful.
We are alerted when something big happens.
But you can also see that the sentiment right was pretty positive up till the end of August and then there was this big turn.
So the crossover and then the sentiment remained negative throughout the rest of the year.
And the important thing to notice here.
Is that the sentiment crossover happens actually before this drastic price plunge, right?
So this was like the first nice thing to see when we plotted this chart and then we went on to computing causality tests.
So basically we wanted to see whether the sentiment helps predicting the price.
Or does the price basically helps predicting the sentiment.
The preliminary results, but they're very preliminary.
They showed that actually, the the sentiment would predict would help predicting the price and not vice versa, right?
So but before.
Before we all get very rich.
By selling you this technology because we don't want to play with our money on the stock market.

We of course need to do some more large scale tests to see if this is true, but currently what we believe is that in some cases this is true, so we can actually help predicting the price by looking at the sentiment, but which cases these are?
This is not completely clear right now.
OK, so I will conclude here.
So what I will just recap what I was talking about right?
Now so.
On Twitter, people are definitely expressing opinions about stocks extensively, right?
We acquire these tweets and we analyze the vocabulary to see whether it's positive or negative, and then we can display the results along the timeline and observe sentiment trends through time.
And yeah, our preliminary causality tests are positive.
So.
So that's it.
Thank you for your attention.
I just wanted to understand whether this platform is aimed as being rolled out on various languages.
Because you're saying that you're only taking into account English, which is certainly the most spoken English, the most spoken language in the world.
But I am planning to include also let's say Spanish or French or German.
Even yeah, the technology that we are currently using.
It's based on statistics and in statistics with this kind of methods it it helps to have a lot of data, right?
So when we go for US stocks and for English we kind of get quite a lot of data, which is not the case if we go for some other markets.
So I would expect that we wouldn't be so successful in researching this with other markets, but it's definitely something that we could try.
Because in the end, the technology that we employ is quite language independent, so it's not a problem to process Spanish language or Italian language.
That's not the problem.

The problem is just in the amount of data and having something that we call the training set the training base, which means a lot of tweets in a particular language already, manually or somehow credibly labeled as positive and negative.
So for English we have all these things.

If I use a technology like these four to measure the opinion of the of a social community about a company, do I need to have somebody in a company in my company to teach the technology about slangs and how humans user how humans communicate short toward the end zone?

So what we have for this particular in this particular case, the technology that was employed here is based on machine learning, which means that you don't need somebody to model the vocabulary, or you know the the way people talk about companies.
But you need to have training data.
This means that you need to have a lot of tweets that have positive and negative labels manually assigned to them in a way you need.
Somebody has to make this.
Assignments of labels to tweets, but then you put all this knowledge into an algorithm that learns how to apply labels to other tweets that don't have the labels yet.
Was this to technical?
You know people communication changes over the time, correct?
So if you want to so you also have.

For many machine learning algorithms such as this one, you have something called online varients of these algorithms, which means that the model is online receiving the data, but then adapts through time.
But he the IT needs to have the labels.
So so if you want to update the model, you need to somehow get the Golden standard labels.
For example, this is a very simple one, so Greece.
The mentioning of Greece was very positive, you know, vacation Sun Islands and so on a couple of years ago, but today.
It's it's a different story, so this is what you were talking about, right?
So it is possible to adopt yes, but it's not without any cost.
But what you were presenting seems to be something extremely savvy to those who are playing around with stocks etc.
Is excuse me if I'm I'm so straightforward.
Misha is there a timeline where you're planning to roll that out and make it available to the great public in order to be acquired?
So definitely yes.
So these are our preliminary results, and it's a kind of a teaser for for everybody here in the room, right?
But we definitely plan to do a proper evaluation with all trying to rule out all the elements of randomness.
Or you know, neutrons or whatever coming from from the space, and we will publish a paper on this definitely.
And actually a couple of papers like this appeared recently.
Papers that claim that there is a correlation, even proof not just claim there's a correlation between the.
Volume of search in search queries and the trading volume of a particular stock, and we notice the correlation a pretty good correlation between.
Mentioning in Twitter and trading volume, but up until now nobody was reporting any correlation between the price and whatever else, right?
So let's see what happens.
Thank you.
